The statue is carefully carved out of a single rock, standing at a height of 6.7 meters. The deity sitting in a cross-legged yoga pose above the coils of the mighty seven-headed serpent, Adisesha, is awe-inspiring.

Narasimha's finely sculpted broad chest, flowing mane and his headdress as he sits cross-legged on the coils of Adisesha, the king of all snakes. Adisesha's seven hoods rise behind him, forming a magnificent canopy over Narasimha's head. A lion's mask is also placed above within a makara torana or arch.

The lost idol of Goddess Lakshmi
Built by the visionary king Krishnadevaraya in the 15th century, the Lakshmi Narasimha temple is a testimony to the enduring legacy of the Vijayanagara Empire. The original idol had a small figure of Goddess Lakshmi, Narasimha's wife, seated on his lap. However, the idol was damaged during the invasion of the Mughals in 1565 AD. During this attack, the limbs of the idol of Narasimha were shattered, and the idol of Goddess Lakshmi was separated from his lap.  As a result, one of the idol's arms was broken, and even today the goddess's broken arm can be seen resting on Narasimha's back as a poignant reminder of the temple's turbulent history. The damaged idol of Goddess Lakshmi was eventually found and can be seen today in the Archaeological Museum at Kamalapura.

Hampi is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. In the 14th century, it became the centre of the Hindu Vijayanagara Empire. Many chronicles left by Persian and European travellers, especially Portuguese, state that Hampi was a prosperous, wealthy and grand city near the¬†river Tungabhadra, with several temples, farms and markets. By 1500¬†CE, Hampi-Vijayanagara was known to be the world's second-largest medieval-era city after¬†Beijing, and perhaps India's richest at the time. Hampi attracted many traders from Persia and Portugal. The Vijayanagara Empire was defeated by a coalition of Muslim sultanates. During the seige that followed, its capital was conquered, pillaged and destroyed by the sultanate armies in 1565, after which Hampi remained in ruins.
I went to Hampi in December 2012 & explored the magnificent Hampi over 3 full days. The city of Hampi lay there with all its brilliance, bedecked with the jewels of innumerable temples, bazaars, ponds, pillars, monuments, elephant stables, bathing places, the royal enclosure, & many more. Important places NEVER TO BE MISSED at Hampi include - Viroopaaksha temple & market complex, Krishna temple & market complex, Vitthala temple & market complex, the stone chariot, Hazaara Rama temple, Hemakoota hills, Veerabhadra temple, the royal enclosure, Mahaanavami dibba, infrastructural facilities within the royal enclosure, water supply systems, Lotus Mahal, the elephant stables, Badavi Linga, Yoga Nrisimha, saasive kaalu Ganesha, kadale kaalu Ganesha, the King's balance, raaja beedi (path of the royal family), purandara mantapa, & many more. Hampi is a gut wrenching experience. The magnificent city is completely in ruins. Almost every temple, except the Viroopaaksha temple is in ruins. Every deity has been mutilated. Every temple has been burned, so much so that, to this day we can see the blackening of temple roofs because of the burning. Every stone, every brick, every single piece of art & architecture has a story to tell; a story that is heartbreaking. Every temple cries for the deity it housed. The musical pillars of the Vitthala temple has become mute without its Lord Vitthala. The Pattaabhiraama temple is like a giant elephant without its master, lifeless. Every pillar, every stone wails in agony. The magnitude of the ruins is such that, a true history buff will be left spellbound at the sheer scale of destruction that has been caused. Hampi is also regarded as the place where the legendary Hanumaan, that greatest of Shri Raama's devotees lived in the Kingdom of Kishkindha. It is widely believed that Shri Raama came to Kishkindha, seeking the friendship of Sugreeva, in his pursuit of finding Mother Seeta. During this time, Sugreeva entrusted Hanumaan the task of assisting Raama in finding Seeta. These & many more stories from the Raamaayana is beautifully carved on the walls of Hazaara Raama temple. Then there's the Badavi Linga, which is believed to be built by a poor lady (badavi in Kannada) who was a devotee of Shiva. Just across is the famous Yoga Nrisimha, which also is mutilated. It is believed that it was Lakshmi Nrisimha originally, but, during the siege of Hampi, it got mutilated.
During our visit, we had stayed at Hospet, & travelled to Hampi every day. It is advisable to spend sufficient time exploring, learning, & digesting the amazing Hampi. Do not hurry. Let Hampi overwhelm you with its sheer magnificence, brilliance, & beauty. Allow every rock, every pillar, every monument, every temple, speak to you. Let Hampi sink into your hearts. Krishna Bazaar is a relatively newly excavated site in Hampi. As the name indicates this Bazaar is associated with the Krishna Temple. Basically this was the car street for the temple. The sacred tank (Pushkarni) of the temple too is located next to the Krishna Bazaar.

Thanks to the low laying terrain the whole bazaar got buried in silt over the time. This area later turned into thickets of banana plantations. Before the excavations it was impossible to tell that it was a marketplace once.

Hazara Rama Temple in Hampi is a captivating gem that beautifully showcases the artistry of the Vijayanagara Empire. The outer walls are richly decorated with scenes of royal processions, military displays, and divine figures, offering a glimpse into the grandeur of its historical context. The craftsmanship is exceptional, with ornately carved pillars and a spacious lawn enhancing its charm.

Visiting Hazara Rama Temple is free, and photography is encouraged, making it an ideal spot for both history enthusiasts and casual tourists. The temple is open daily from 6 AM to 6 PM, with the best time to visit being between November and February. Overall, Hazara Rama Temple is a must-see for anyone exploring Hampi's rich cultural heritage.

On the southern side of the Hemakuta Hill in Hampi lies the amazing Lakshmi Narasimha Temple, which houses the awe-inspiring lion-man incarnation of Lord Vishnu, Narasimha. He is one of the ten most powerful incarnations of Lord Vishnu.

Standing proudly as the largest monolithic statue in Hampi, this imposing figure depicts the fierce form of the deity called Ugra Narasimha. The bulging eyes of Lord Vishnu and the intense expression on his face serve as the inspiration behind the name. The statue is carefully carved out of a single rock, standing at a height of 6.7 meters. The deity sitting in a cross-legged yoga pose above the coils of the mighty seven-headed serpent, Adisesha, is awe-inspiring.

Narasimha's finely sculpted broad chest, flowing mane and his headdress as he sits cross-legged on the coils of Adisesha, the king of all snakes. Adisesha's seven hoods rise behind him, forming a magnificent canopy over Narasimha's head. A lion's mask is also placed above within a makara torana or arch.

The lost idol of Goddess Lakshmi
Built by the visionary king Krishnadevaraya in the 15th century, the Lakshmi Narasimha temple is a testimony to the enduring legacy of the Vijayanagara Empire. The original idol had a small figure of Goddess Lakshmi, Narasimha's wife, seated on his lap. However, the idol was damaged during the invasion of the Mughals in 1565 AD. During this attack, the limbs of the idol of Narasimha were shattered, and the idol of Goddess Lakshmi was separated from his lap.  As a result, one of the idol's arms was broken, and even today the goddess's broken arm can be seen resting on Narasimha's back as a poignant reminder of the temple's turbulent history. The damaged idol of Goddess Lakshmi was eventually found and can be seen today in the Archaeological Museum at Kamalapura.

The Achyutaraya Temple also known as Tiruvengalanatha (a form of Lord Vishnu) temple, built in 1534 AD by Mahamandeleshwara Hiriya Tirumalraja during the reign of Achyutadeva Raya, is situated in the foothills between the Matanga and Gandhamadhavan hills. Mythically, these hills are associated with the curse of Matanga Rishi due to which Bali could not enter this area and hence the area was a safe haven for Sugriva.

The temple complex includes the main temple as well as associated bazaar and pushkarni (pond). The main temple consists of sanctum sanctorum, antaral, mandap, Devi temple and kalyana mandap. The temple is surrounded by two prakaras. The outer prakara has one gopuram (entrance) and the inner prakara has three gopurams. The open chamber outside the temple is formed by finely carved pillars. The kalyana mandap is also adorned with highly carved pillars.

The distinctive feature of Vijayanagara temples are the tall gopurams and Kalyana mandapams. Over time the gopurams became increasingly taller, in most cases even higher than the vimana (spire) of the temple. The Kalyana mandapam was built to perform the annual marriage ceremony between the main deity and the goddess. The pillars of the Kalyana mandapam have some of the most magnificent carvings. In temples of this period, the sanctum and gopuram walls are built of stone while the vimana is built of bricks.

One of the lesser-known but immensely fascinating sites in Hampi is the underground Shiva Temple, also known as the Prasanna Virupaksha Temple.

Built sometime around 14th Century AD under the reign of King Deva Raya II, this temple, like all the other surviving temples in Hampi, is noted for its impressive architecture and also a large monolithic lingam of Lord Shiva located inside a circular chamber.

Hampi, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is a treasure trove of stunning landscapes and ancient architecture that beckons photographers and travelers alike. Nestled in the heart of Karnataka, this historic town is renowned for its captivating ruins, vibrant bazaars, and breathtaking natural beauty. From the majestic stone chariot at the Vitthala Temple to the serene views atop Matanga Hill, every corner of Hampi offers a unique backdrop that tells a story of its glorious past. Whether you're capturing the intricate carvings of the Hazara Raama Temple or the tranquil sunset views from Hippie Island, Hampi is a canvas waiting to be explored through your lens.

As you wander through the remnants of the Vijayanagara Empire, you'll discover a mix of well-known landmarks and hidden gems that make for perfect photo opportunities. The Elephant Stables, with their impressive Indo-Islamic architecture, and the enchanting Lotus Mahal are just a few highlights that showcase the town's rich heritage. Don't forget to take a Coracle Ride for a different perspective of the temples along the river. With so much to see and capture, Hampi invites you to embark on a photographic journey that celebrates its timeless charm and vibrant culture.
